I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $135,000,000 comprising (i) an A loan of up to $50,000,000 and (ii) a B loan of up to 
$85,000,000,  to  Gulf  PD  Company  Limited  (Gulf  PD)  for  the  Eastern  Economic  Corridor 
Independent Power Project in Thailand. The report also describes the proposed administration of 
a loan of up to $45,000,000 to be provided by the Leading Asia’s Private Infrastructure Fund1 
(LEAP), and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to 
me by the Board, approve the administration of the loan.  
 
2.  The project entails the construction and operation of a 2,500 megawatt (MW) combined 
cycle gas turbine (CCGT) power plant in the Rojana Rayong 2 Industrial Park of Rayong Province. 
The project is being developed under Thailand’s independent power producer (IPP) program and 
will be implemented under a 25-year power purchase agreement (PPA) with the Electricity 
Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT) and a 25-year gas sales agreement with PTT Public 
Company Limited (PTT). The project sponsors are Gulf Energy Development Public Company 
Limited (GED), one of Thailand’s largest power generation companies, and Mitsui & Co., Ltd. 
(Mitsui), one of Japan’s largest trading companies. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
3.  Project identification. With the aim of reaching high-income country status by 2032, 
Thailand launched Thailand 4.0, a development model to pull the country out of the middle-income 
trap by creating a value-based economy driven by innovation. To put Thailand 4.0 into action, the 
Government of Thailand adopted the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) development plan, which 
will be the prime economic growth driver for the country till 2028.2 The EEC development plan 
builds on the Eastern Seaboard Development Program (ESDP), which is credited with the 
country’s  rapid  industrial  transformation.  The  ESDP,  launched  in  1982,  established  major 
industries along Thailand’s eastern seaboard (e.g., petrochemicals, electronics, and automotive 
parts) and facilitated major investments in infrastructure (e.g., ports, highways, power plants, 
water supply, and industrial estates).  
 
4.  During 1982–2002, the ESDP contributed remarkable annual growth rates in export values 
(12%), industrial sector expansion (12%), and gross domestic product (7%). The national poverty 
level declined substantially from 67% in 1986 to below 9% in 2016. However, Thailand’s economy 
then began to stagnate at middle-income levels, preventing it from graduating to the ranks of high-
income countries. Building on the success of the ESDP, the government aims to promote the next 
generation of industries and infrastructure through its flagship EEC development plan. This 
includes mega public–private partnership projects centered on transport and logistics––e.g., 
international airport expansion (U-Tapao), deep sea port expansion (Map Ta Phut and Laem 
Chabang), the country’s first high-speed train connecting the three major international airports 
(Suvarnabhumi,  Don  Muang,  and  U-Tapao)––and  other  investments  in  industry,  tourism, 
hospitals, and smart cities.3 In the first 5 years, the total investment is estimated to amount B1.7 
 
1  Financing partner: Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA). 
2  The EEC development plan will be implemented across an area of more than 13,000 square kilometers in the three 
eastern provinces of Chachoengsao, Chonburi, and Rayong. 
3  The EEC development plan aims to promote 10 industry clusters: (i) next-generation automotive, (ii) intelligent 
electronics, (iii) advanced agriculture and biotechnology, (iv) food processing, (v) tourism, (vi) advanced robotics,

2 
trillion ($55 billion), of which B1.4 trillion will be from the private sector. Infrastructure investment 
accounts for 44% at B752 billion. Based on these investments, the EEC development plan is 
expected to achieve economic growth of 5%, create more than 100,000 jobs, and attract 10 million 
more tourists annually. 
 
5.  One of the major challenges of the EEC development plan is how to finance these 
investments because of its unprecedented scale and because the majority of the investment will 
be made by the private sector or through a public–private partnership. Although Thailand has 
established a robust local banking sector, which is liquid and provides long-term local currency 
financing that is suitable for infrastructure projects, local banks alone will not be able to fund all 
the investments under the EEC development plan.4 On the other hand, local banks and a small 
number of international banks, namely Japanese, have dominated Thailand’s infrastructure 
financing market. Aside from three Japanese mega-banks, the Japan Bank for International 
Cooperation (JBIC), and the Asian Development Bank (ADB), only two international banks have 
financed multiple infrastructure projects in Thailand since 2009. This contrasts with regional peers 
such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore, which have more international banks in their 
infrastructure finance markets.5 Therefore, mobilizing international lenders with limited experience 
in Thailand will be key for successfully financing the EEC development plan.  
 
6.  The  Eastern  Economic  Corridor  Independent  Power  Project  provides  an  excellent 
opportunity to secure international lenders for the EEC development plan. An IPP centrally located 
in the EEC, it is one of the key utility projects under the EEC development plan. The project will 
be the fourth-largest power plant and one of the largest CCGT power plants in the country. It will 
become fully operational by 2024, which coincides with the EEC development plan’s expected 
increase in energy demand and Thailand’s largest decommissioning of aging power plants; more 
than 8,500 MW will retire between 2020 and 2025 (equivalent to 20% of current national capacity). 
The project will also help ensure reliable and cost-effective power in the EEC because of its high 
efficiency relative to other plants in the area. It will use natural gas and employ the latest CCGT 
technology with a maximum rated efficiency of greater than 63%.

7.  Project design. The project is being developed under Thailand’s IPP program, which 
allows the private sector to build, own, and operate power projects with a generating capacity of 
more than 90 MW. The program was established in 1994 to promote efficient procurement and 
foster competition to minimize the government’s capital burden and lower the cost of electricity. 
IPP contracts are awarded through a bidding process based on the lowest levelized electricity 
price. Since its inception, the program has successfully tendered three IPP bidding rounds and 
awarded 13 contracts totaling more than 16,000 MW. The EEC Independent Power Project was 
awarded the contract in the latest IPP bidding round, which concluded in 2013. 
 
8.  The project entails the construction and operation of a 2,500 MW CCGT power plant in 
the Rojana Rayong 2 Industrial Park of Rayong Province, about 150 kilometers (km) southeast of

B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
12.  Impact. The project is aligned with Thailand 4.0, the government’s strategy designed to 
promote and support innovation, creativity, research and development, higher technologies, and 
green technologies.7 It will also help improve Thailand’s power system stability and reliability.8 
 
13.  Outcome. The project’s outcome is an increased delivery of stable and reliable power to 
the EEC area. Annually, the project will deliver at least 16,000 gigawatt-hours of electricity. When 
compared to the existing energy mix in Thailand, the project will avoid at least 1 million tons of 
carbon dioxide equivalent emissions per annum.9

C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
15.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. Following ADB’s Strategy 2030, 
the project meets the operational priorities of tackling climate change, building climate and 
disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability.10 Furthermore,  the  project 
supports private sector participation in infrastructure to fill the infrastructure gap and catalyze and 
mobilize financial resources for development.11 ADB’s support for the project is in line with its 
country partnership strategy, 2013–2016 for Thailand12 and its country operations business plan, 
2019–2021,13 both of which promote the support for private sector development and energy 
infrastructure, and respond to Thailand’s needs and priorities as an upper middle-income country. 
 
16.  Consistency with sector strategy and associated ADB operations. The project is 
consistent with ADB’s Energy Policy,14 which emphasizes investments in energy efficiency, least-
cost supply, and private sector participation. ADB supports projects that use efficient technologies 
such as CCGT or incorporate state-of-the-art emission control equipment. 
 
17.  Lessons from previous operations. The award of the PPA and the preparation of the 
project were done together with the Chonburi Natural Gas Power Project that received a direct 
ADB loan of $228 million.15

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
19.  ADB’s proposed assistance consists of (i) a proposed A loan of up to $50 million, (ii) a 
proposed B loan of up to $85 million, and (iii) a proposed parallel loan of up to $45 million to be 
provided by LEAP and administered by ADB. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED  
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
20.  The financing needs of the project are substantial, requiring about $1.15 billion of long-
term,  limited-recourse  debt.  ADB’s  assistance  of  $50  million  is  catalyzing  $894  million  of 
cofinancing including a $85 million B loan and a $45 million LEAP parallel loan. This means about 
$18 of cofinancing for every $1 of ADB assistance. ADB has been engaged in the financial 
structuring from early on, and its role as an anchor lender provides credibility to the project and 
its developers to help attract other financial institutions to participate. Furthermore, the B loan 
enables  international  banks  that  have  limited  experience  in  Thailand  to  participate.  The 
mobilization of these new lenders will help diversify the lender base in Thailand’s infrastructure 
financing market, which is key for huge investments expected under the EEC development plan. 
ADB also supports the project’s use of the most advanced technology in terms of high-efficiency

6 
and low-carbon, which has a maximum rated efficiency of greater than 63%. Together with 
Chonburi, the project will be one of the first commercial deployments of MHPS’s most advanced 
and efficient turbine; ADB’s endorsement and the subsequent demonstration may lead to other 
developers adopting it faster and reduce the perceived risk by other financial institutions. 
 
21.  ADB plays a lead role in the due diligence process––especially concerning environmental, 
social, gender, and integrity standards––and in the negotiations and structuring of the transaction. 
More specifically, ADB will require the project to adopt more stringent safeguard measures than 
national standards require and insist on certain gender elements, such as employment targets for 
women and gender-based violence (GBV) initiatives.

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
22.  ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009) as follows: environment (category A), involuntary resettlement (category C), 
and indigenous peoples (category C).17 A draft environmental and social impact assessment 
(ESIA) and management plans were prepared by Gulf PD and disclosed on ADB’s website on 17 
May 2019.18  
 
23.  ADB undertook due diligence and reviewed the project’s potential environmental and 
social impacts and the measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the adverse 
impacts in the safeguard reports and plans. The ESIA was updated to meet ADB’s requirements. 
The environmental and social measures and the institutional capacity and commitment of Gulf 
PD to manage the project’s social and environmental impacts are deemed adequate. 
 
24.  Environment. The key construction phase impacts will include temporary noise, dust, 
traffic, solid and liquid waste generation, hazardous substances, and occupational and public 
health and safety issues. During operation, key potential impacts include air and noise emissions, 
and effluent discharges. The ESIA management plans will avoid, minimize, and mitigate the 
expected impacts and risks. Stack emissions will comply with applicable guidelines and national 
standards. Air dispersion modeling confirmed that national ambient air quality standards will be 
met, and the project will not contribute more than 25% of the national standards at sensitive 
receptor locations.19 The ESIA considered cumulative impacts on the air quality combined with 
the impact from other power plants operating and planned within 15 km of the project. The noise 
calculation results for construction and operation indicated that noise levels will be elevated by 
less than 3 A-weighted decibels at the nearest sensitive receptors if the proposed temporary and 
permanent noise barriers are installed. The ESIA confirmed that effluent discharges will not have

25.  Social. The project is located in Rojana Rayong 2 Industrial Park and covers an area of 
approximately 492 rai (79 hectares). The ESIA and ADB due diligence found no legacy issues 
regarding the historical transfer of the project land. EGAT will construct the proposed transmission 
line.  The  proposed  alignment,  based  on  an  alternative  route  analysis,  avoids  physical 
displacement. An assessment of EGAT’s right-of-way acquisition procedures was undertaken as 
part of due diligence. The land compensation (for the tower and the right of way) is based on 
market value and considers any losses during the construction and maintenance phases. Gulf 
PD  will  participate  in  EGAT’s  ongoing  consultations  process  with  landowners  and  other 
stakeholders to address any concerns. The ESIA recorded no presence of distinct and vulnerable 
indigenous peoples or ethnic minority groups in the project’s area of influence. The social due 
diligence confirmed the same. 
 
26.  Gender and other social dimensions. The project is classified as having some gender 
elements. Gulf PD will provide at least 15% of total employment in the operation phase to women 
and implement the initiatives to prevent GBV during the construction phase. This will include (i) 
making zero tolerance policies and enforcing a code of conduct, (ii) having GBV signs across 
construction sites and labor camps, (iii) assigning focal points to deal with GBV issues, and (iv) 
making GBV training mandatory for all staff and contractors on site. Gulf PD will comply with 
national labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy (2001), will take measures 
to comply with the internationally recognized core labor standards.20 The client will report regularly 
to ADB on (i) its and its contractors’ compliance with such laws and (ii) the measures taken. 
Information disclosure and consultation with affected people will follow ADB requirements.21 
Progress on the agreed gender actions will be monitored during ADB staff supervision visits and 
lender’s technical adviser visits, and will be included in the company’s annual monitoring report. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
27.  Gulf PD was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating 
to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that 
the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance.
